POWERED by FUSION

An individual post follows.

San Francisco Day 3 (Jan 16 2005)

Sunday morning took Phil and I back to the Haight to stop at Future Primitive and Upper Playground, two local purveyors of underground hip-hop fashion, music, and culture. I found a few sartorial gems and was generally inspired, realizing that somewhere there exists clothing that’s street without being blinged-out, designed without being pretentious, stylish without being poncey (note to self: more such boutiques, less AX).

We then took BART to Berkley and wandered the main drags, somewhat unimpressed (not that we were expecting anything in particular). A nice lunch at a chain pho joint powered excessive comic book buying at Comic Relief, which now has all my money. While at the register the cashier’s friend burst in clutching a copy of Dr. Dre’s “The Chronic” and proceeded to relate a hilarious tale of retrieving the CD from his brother’s room before said sibling was hauled off to jail for grand theft auto. It’s those charming moments that really make a vacation.

After a brief rest at the house and a lovely dinner at Chow we took the MUNI down to the beach. Now, this took some sinking in for me: you can take public transit to the Pacific Ocean. On a whim. And until quite late. You can, as I did, watch the moonlight on the water for half an hour without speaking so much as a word to your companions, without thinking much more than “that’s gorgeous.” And then it’s back to the city, the beauty of the water happily waiting for you to return.

Unfathomable.

—Jan 25, 2005
